content.text: On Fig. 1.1, measure the unstretched length \(l_0\) of the spring, in mm
Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring using the equation \(e = l - l_0\)
Calculate a value for the spring constant \(k\) using the equation \(k = \frac{F}{e}\), where \(F = 3.0 \text{N}\)
The student attaches the spring to the clamp as shown in Fig. 1.2
He hangs a \(300\mathrm{g}\) mass on the spring
He measures the new length \(l\) of the spring
Record the time \(t\) taken for 10 complete oscillations
1. Calculate the time \(T\) taken for one complete oscillation
2. Calculate \(T^2\)
Calculate the spring constant \(k\) using the equation \(k = \frac{0.040m}{T^2}\) , where \(m = 0.300 \text{kg}\)
The student pulls the mass down a short distance and releases it so that it oscillates up and down. Fig. 1.3 shows the time \(t\) taken for 10 complete oscillations
State and explain whether your two values for \(k\) are the same within the limits of experimental accuracy
statement
explanation
A student states that repeating Method 1 with different masses would improve the reliability of the value obtained for \(k\)
Suggest additional values for the mass \(m\) that you would use when repeating the experiment to improve the reliability
[Total: 11]
A student is determining the spring constant \(k\) of a spring by two methods
Fig. 1.2 shows how the apparatus is used
Record the current \(I\) in the circuit, as shown on the ammeter in Fig. 2.2

The student places the sliding contact \(\mathbf{C}\) at a distance \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{P}\). The voltmeter reading is shown in Fig. 2.3. Record the voltmeter reading in Table 2.1 for \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\). [1]
The student repeats the procedure using values of \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}\), \(60.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(100.0 \text{cm}\). The readings are shown in Table 2.1
Complete the column headings in the table
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(l / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0, 0)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of each centimetre of the wire. Use the equation \(R = \frac{Gk}{I}\), where \(k = 1.0 \text{V/cm}\) and where \(I\) is the current recorded in (a)
Include the unit
[Total: 11]
A student is determining the resistance of a piece of wire
Fig. 2.1 shows the circuit she uses
On Fig. 3.1:
• draw a normal **NL** at the centre of side **AB**
• continue the normal so that it passes through side **CD** of the block
• label the point **F** where **NL** crosses **AB**
• label the point **G** where **NL** crosses **CD**
Draw a line **EF** at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the left of the normal and above side **AB**
Mark the positions of two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line **EF** placed at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-tracing experiment
• Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) . Continue the line until it meets the normal **NL**
• Label the point **H** where the line meets side **CD**. Draw the line **FH**
Measure and record the length \(a\) of the line **GH**
Measure and record the length \(b\) of the line **FH**
Calculate the refractive index \(n\) using the equation \(n = \frac{0.5b}{a}\)
The student observes the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side **CD** of the block so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other

He places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between his eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\) , \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are marked on Fig. 3.1
The student repeats the procedure using the angle of incidence \(i = 45^{\circ}\)
Calculate the refractive index \(n\), using the equation \(n = \frac{0.71b}{a}\)
The student expected the two values of refractive index \(n\) obtained in this experiment to be equal
State two difficulties with this type of experiment that could explain any difference in the two values of \(n\)
A student suggests precautions to take in this experiment to obtain reliable results
Tick one box to indicate the most sensible suggestion
Carry out the experiment in a darkened room
Use pins that are taller than the height of the block
View the bases of the pins
View the pins with one eye closed
[Total: 11]
A student is determining the refractive index \(n\) of the material of a transparent block
Fig. 3.1 shows the outline \(\mathbf{ABCD}\) of the transparent block

A student is investigating the relationship between the power produced by an electrical heater and the time taken to heat a beaker of water. The power of the heater is given by the equation \(P = VI\), where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the heater and \(I\) is the current in the heater
Plan an experiment to investigate the relationship between the power produced by an electrical heater and the time taken to heat a beaker of water
The following apparatus is available:
ammeter
voltmeter
0–12 V variable power supply
250 cm³ beaker
heater
thermometer
stopwatch
The student can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory
You should:
· complete the diagram in Fig. 4.1 to show the circuit that you would use
· explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation
· state the key variables that you would control
· draw a table with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how you would use your results to reach a conclusion
